Education.area: Thesis: Simulation of Quantum Homomorphic Encryption
Education.abstract:
When interacting with a cloud server, two ideals we could aim for, among others, are performing computation and ensuring the privacy of the data. Quantum homomorphic encryption is a cryptographic primitive that seeks to address these two objectives in the quantum setting, allowing for quantum computation on encrypted quantum data. In this work, we provide a software simulation of a quantum homomorphic encryption scheme, known as the "EPR scheme", for universal quantum circuits, developed by Broadbent and Jeffery.
We demonstrate the near-term viability of this scheme and provide evidence that the computational cost of classical subroutines in the simulation is negligible compared to the cost of simulating the quantum operations. The simulation package is an open-source Python implementation, called "py-qhe-epr", with a focus on extensive documentation and ease of use for educational, verification and adaptability purposes, supporting future research and development. Furthermore, this implementation serves as a step towards further hardware applications of quantum homomorphic encryption between networked quantum devices.
Education.studyType: Master of Science in Quantum Cryptography

In particular, he used the idea of light quanta (photons) to explain experimental results, but stressed the importance of the experimental results. The importance of his work on the photoelectric effect earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.

keywords.name: The Sixth IEEE International Conference on Trust, Privacy and Security (TPS) in Intelligent Systems, and Applications
summary: Presented work related to the paper Simulation of Quantum Homomorphic Encryption: Demonstration and Analysis
Confrence Co-located with IEEE CIC 2024 & IEEE CogMI 2024, offering rich networking opportunities, inlcuding a keynote by Ed Chi from Google
Featuerd panel dicsussions, technical sessions and workshops on quantum computing and AI integration, as well as AI governance and policy
keywords.description: A conference exploring the latest advancements in quantum computing technologies.

keywords.name: IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering – QCE24
keywords.description: A gathering of top quantum computing researchers.
summary: Presented a poster on the extended abstract Demonstrating Quantum Homomorphic Encryption Through Simulation
Attended various talks, workshops, panels, and poster sessions on topics like quantum algorithms, cryptography, error correction, and emerging quantum technologies

Participated in student mentorship events, networking sessions, and the career fair, building valuable connections with organizations like IonQ, Quantinuum, Qblox, and others across industry, government, and academia.
Over 1,600 registrants, including students, academics, and industry experts, fostering interdisciplinary collaboration
Notable speakers included Jay Gambetta (IBM Quantum) and Josh Izaac (Xanadu), among others, sharing insights on quantum computing and software development

keywords.name: 2024 Québec Ontario Consortium on Quantum Protocols (QUORUM) Meeting
summary: A two-day event featuring discussions on recent advancements in quantum technologies, with a focus on QUORUM’s main themes: entanglement, cryptography, communications, and governance

Included a variety of talks by researchers from institutions such as the University of Waterloo, University of Ottawa, Université de Montréal, McGill University, Université de Sherbrooke, and internationally from Technische Universität München, along with industrial partners like Quantum Bridge Technologies, IonQ, and Ki3 Photonics

keywords.name: 2024 Quantum BC Research Day
summary: A full-day event held at the University of British Columbia, bringing together faculty, industry professionals, and students engaged in quantum technologies

Featuring a keynote by Dr. Pooya Ronagh of 1QBit, research talks by leading scientists such as Dr. Daochen Wang (UBC) and Dr. Matt Amy (SFU), panel discussions with experts from Rigetti and D-Wave, engaging poster sessions, and valuable networking opportunities

keywords.name: Inside Quantum Technologies
summary: A three-day conference centered on the commercialization and business aspects of quantum technologies, featuring technical talks, panels, talent development sessions, and discussions on quantum tech adoption and Canada's vision for quantum technologies

Included celebrated speakers like Gilles Brassard, one of the two developers of the BB84 protocol, alongside industry leaders such as D-Wave, Xanadu, and Pasqal, providing excellent networking opportunities

keywords.name: 2023 The Canadian Mathematical Society (CMS) Summer Meeting
summary: A three-day meeting featuring a variety of sessions, including topics such as quantum information theory, C*-algebras and their applications, advances in AI/ML, and more

The meeting brought together renowned speakers from government institutions like the Bank of Canada and the Tutte Institute, as well as academic institutions such as the University of Waterloo, through diverse formats including talks and poster presentations

keywords.name: Quantum Days 2023
summary: Brought together participants from across Canada’s quantum community, including students, researchers, industry professionals, policymakers, and investors
Featured poster sessions, a career fair, scientific talks, and panel discussions on a wide range of topics
Included representatives from cutting-edge institutions and companies like Xanadu and IBM, as well as renowned researchers such as Dr. Gilles Brassard, Dr. Anne Broadbent, and Dr. Elham Kashefi

keywords.name: Fall 2022 INTRIQ meeting
summary: A two-day gathering organized by INTRIQ (Institut Transdisciplinaire d'Information Quantique), bringing together members of the quantum information community for discussions, presentations, and networking
Featured primarily experimental subjects from notable speakers like Dr. Ebrahim Karimi (University of Ottawa) and Dr. Roger Melko (Perimeter Institute, Waterloo)

keywords.name: British Columbia’s Undergraduate Mathematics & Statistics Conference
summary: A two-day event designed to support undergraduate students in mathematics and statistics across British Columbia, fostering research and collaborative opportunities
Included a variety of talks by students, alongside speakers from academia and industry, as well as networking opportunities, workshops, and panel discussions

keywords.name: International Summer School in Quantum Technologies 2023
summary: A 10-day summer school at the University of Birmingham, bringing together 60 researchers from the UK and Canada, aimed at fostering collaboration and nurturing talent development in quantum technologies among early-career researchers

Featured talks by leading experts in quantum technologies, covering areas such as communication, computing, imaging, and sensing, including Dr. Norbert Lütkenhaus (University of Waterloo, Canada), Dr. Elham Kashefi (University of Edinburgh, UK), Dr. Síle Nic Chormaic (Okinawa Institute of Science and Technology, Japan), and Dr. John Kitching (NIST, USA)

Included poster sessions, workshops, and discussion panels on topics like career development, responsible innovation, trusted research, commercialization, and equality, diversity, and inclusion (EDI), providing excellent opportunities for networking with early-career researchers from Canada and the UK

keywords.name: Quantum Key Distribution Summer School
summary: The five-day program, held at the state-of-the-art Quantum-Nano Centre at the University of Waterloo, focused on the theoretical and experimental aspects of quantum communication with a particular emphasis on quantum cryptography, featuring participants affiliated with institutions from Canada, Spain, Italy, Poland, and the USA

Delivered cutting-edge insights on topics such as information-theoretic security, post-quantum cryptography, and quantum hacking, with lectures by top researchers including Dr. Norbert Lütkenhaus, Dr. Michele Mosca, Dr. David Jao (University of Waterloo), Dr. Renato Renner, and Dr. Ramona Wolf (ETH Zürich)

keywords.name: IPAM Graduate Summer School on Post-quantum and Quantum Cryptography
summary: Hosted by the Institute for Pure and Applied Mathematics (IPAM) at the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA), the event provided an in-depth introduction to post-quantum and quantum cryptography. Topics included the Deutsch-Jozsa algorithm, Simon's algorithm, the BB84 protocol, quantum key distribution, and Supersingular Isogeny Key Encapsulation (now broken). Featured speakers included top researchers such as Dr. Anne Broadbent, Dr. Craig Costello, and Dr. Jonathan Katz
Presented a poster titled Inner Workings of SHA-512 during the interactive session

keywords.name: PIMS CRG Summer School: Deep Learning for Computational Mathematics
summary: A summer school hosted at Simon Fraser University, exploring the intersection of deep learning and computational mathematics. The program emphasized applying machine learning techniques and TensorFlow to solve complex mathematical problems, tailored for students
Featured three days of lectures and hands-on tutorials, followed by a one-day workshop

keywords.name: Data Science Bootcamp
summary: A two-week Data Science Bootcamp held at the University of Saskatchewan, primarily designed for graduate and senior undergraduate students, covering foundational and advanced topics in data science

Explored in-depth topics such as an introduction to machine learning, data visualization, and varied case studies, with sessions led by researchers like Dr. Linglong Kong, Dr. Stephen Kobourov, and Dr. Nathaniel Osgood

keywords.name: 2018 PIMS BC Data Science Workshop
summary: A one-week workshop held at the University of British Columbia, designed for students from PIMS institutions with strong mathematical backgrounds and an interest in data science, including both theoretical and practical components with data sets and problems from industry and government.

Using Jupyter Notebook, Pandas, and NumPy, I contributed to the Predicting Heavy Equipment Failure project for SSR Mining as part of a 9-person team. At the project's workshop presentation (link), I presented an analysis of six trucks, highlighting potential failure points for one in particular. This analysis generated interest from SSR stakeholders and initiated follow-up conversations.
Featured a career panel at the KPMG Vancouver office, offering insights into industry career options for mathematicians.

nested_items: Analyzing user opinion of call quality and network performance of a VoIP PBX with CloudPBX.
Connecting genetic mutations to cytokine levels at St. Paul’s Hospital.
Determining intent and automating knowledge base creation from live chat transcripts with Comm100.
Interpolating ship paths in the Port of Metro Vancouver with SNC-Lavalin Inc.

keywords.name: QHack 2023 by Xanadu
keywords.description: A 48-hour hackathon for building quantum-powered solutions.
summary:
Collaborated in a team of three to implement Cryptography with Certified Deletion by James Bartusek and Dakshita Khurana, building on the foundational work Quantum Encryption with Certified Deletion by Anne Broadbent and Rabib Islam:
These primitives enable a party in possession of a quantum ciphertext to generate a classical certificate that the encrypted plaintext has been information-theoretically deleted, and cannot be recovered even given unbounded computational resources.
The project also incorporated the post-quantum cryptosystem NTRU and utilized visualization techniques to effectively demonstrate the results

nested_items: A global quantum hackathon hosted by Xanadu’s Pennylane platform
bringing together over 2000 participants from around the world to collaborate on quantum computing challenges
with experts from leading quantum organizations such as IBM, Google, and AWS Braket, covering topics like quantum machine learning and quantum algorithms

keywords.name: 2023 iQuHACK by MIT - IonQ Challenge
summary: Collaborated in a team of three to tackle the IonQ challenge (link), which involved encoding the Fashion MNIST dataset into quantum states and classifying them

nested_items: A global quantum hackathon hosted by MIT's Interdisciplinary Quantum Information Science and Engineering (iQuISE), bringing together participants from academia, industry, and startups to solve quantum computing challenges
Hackathon challenges spanned various topics such as quantum algorithms, error correction, quantum machine learning, and quantum hardware optimization.

keywords.name: Data Science Case Competition at the British Columbia’s Undergraduate Mathematics & Statistics Conference
summary: Within team of two, analyzed delay trends for each of BC Ferries’ boats, taking into consideration each boat as well as features such as temperature, traffic, and wind
Created graphs in Python (matplotlib) to create data visualization, highlighting ferries with most delays
Rewarded first place $400 prize for excellent data visualization and presentation

summary.nested_header: About Data Science Case Competition at BCUMSC:
nested_items: A data science case competition, organized as a distinct event within the broader British Columbia’s Undergraduate Mathematics & Statistics Conference.

The competition involved analyzing BC Ferries’ dataset to identify correlations between delays and various features such as traffic, weather conditions, vessel names, departure times, and arrival times
